answers.author: Kenneth Parker
answers.text:
Port Orange, Florida has equipment in each of our Fire Stations and at our Police Headquarters Building.  The funding for the equipment came from general revenues.  Additionally, the City has an agreement with the YMCA.  The City owns the building and leases it to the local Y.  They are required to maintain the facility, provide the equipment, and pay the operating cost.  All City employees are allowed to use the facility.  The only cost is the Social Security value of the benefit.  Our Police civilian employees are free to use the facility at the Police Headquarters building.  Our Fire civilian employees are able to use the equipment at either the Police Headquarters Building or at any of the Fire Stations.   The program has been well received by our employees and occasionally does receive some comments from the Public.  The City Council has stated that it is part of our overall health and fitness program.  Employees who are healthy have fewer lost days due to sickness and injury.  Employees who are on workers compensation and are in rehab often use these facilities as part of their rehabilitation rather than going to a private facility.   The Physical Therapist will often come to our facility to provide the treatment.

answers.author: Josephine Valencia
answers.text:
I worked for a local government that spent $100,000 on building a fitness center that was shared by employees of Transportation, Solid Waste, and Public Works.  It was funded by general tax revenues.  Police and Fire each had their own fitness centers for several years.   I never heard any complaints from the public about this being a "perk."  If we had, the answer would of been that these employees performed very physical work and we needed them  in top physical shape.  The only complaints we ever got were from employees in other Departments that didn’t have access to these facilities.  All employees were eligible for a reduced membership at the YMCA.   
I worked for another local government that had a very modest fitness center.  Some of the initial funding came from the “Safety and Wellness fund” that was funded through tax revenues.  But the bulk of funds came from a $25 annual fee that employees paid to use the facility.  The justification for that program was that it would reduce obesity and thereby insurance costs.  That savings never materialized.  The facility was used mostly be employees who were already in good health and just appreciated the convenience of having a location at work.

answers.author: Sean Maguire
answers.text:
In lieu of a fitness room, we provide our firefighters with a reimbursement to use a local gym of his or her choice.  The cap for reimbursement is linked to the Town's YMCA single membership rate.  Firefighters (volunteer) must visit the facility at least 20 times per quarter and attend at least 10 percent of alarms (50% reimbursement) and can receive a full reimbursement with more fire call responses.

answers.author: Christine Thompson
answers.text:
Sharonville, Ohio has a fitness room in the basement of the police department which is located at City Hall.  The equipment was obtained by grants and specials funds.  Our 3 fire stations each have fitness rooms as well.  The equipment was purchased through grants and the special fund of the fire department.  I have also negotiated a discount for city employees and their spouses at an in-town bootcamp program.  The local YMCA provides a discount based on the number of employees that become members.
None of these facilities or programs are in the public eye and we have received no backlash.

author: Jeffrey French
text: Does your municipality have a fitness/workout room for employees to use?  If so, from what sources did the equipment come from?  If you have a fitness room, how did you overcome public perception that this was an unnecessary "perk"?
title: Municipally owned fitness or wellness room
